comment: This question really made me think about how I approach learning new technologies. I've been trying to be more intentional about understanding the 'why' behind concepts rather than just memorizing syntax.
Great question! I discovered that learning about event bubbling helped me solve a persistent bug in my React project. Sometimes the most surprising discoveries come from debugging!
I struggled with scope rules for weeks. What helped me was drawing diagrams of the execution context and visualizing how variables are stored in different scopes.
This reminds me of when I first learned about hoisting. It seemed so counterintuitive until I understood that JavaScript moves declarations to the top during compilation.
The most surprising thing I learned this week was about CSS Grid. I always thought it was complicated, but it's actually much more intuitive than Flexbox for complex layouts!
I was amazed to learn that JavaScript is single-threaded but can handle async operations through the event loop. It completely changed how I think about performance!
I faced a huge challenge with understanding promises. What helped was breaking it down into micro-tasks and macro-tasks. Now async/await makes so much more sense!
My biggest challenge was debugging a memory leak in my React app. I learned about cleanup functions in useEffect the hard way, but now I'm much more careful!
I want to develop my TypeScript skills next. I've already started by adding types to my existing JavaScript projects. It's catching so many bugs before they even happen!
Next skill for me is definitely Node.js. I want to understand the full stack. I've started with Express.js and it's been eye-opening to see how the backend works!
